Accelerating lithium-sulfur battery reaction kinetics and inducing 3D deposition of Li2S using interactions between Fe3Se4 and lithium polysulfides Yihan Lin Conceptualization Formal analysis Investigation Methodology Supervision Validation Writing – original draft Liheng Li Data curation Formal analysis Methodology Validation Longjie Tan Data curation Formal analysis Validation Yongliang Li Funding acquisition Resources Writing – review & editing Xiangzhong Ren Project administration Resources Writing – review & editing Peixin Zhang Funding acquisition Software Writing – review & editing Chuanxin He Resources Writing – review & editing Lingna Sun Conceptualization Funding acquisition Project administration Resources Supervision Writing – review & editing ⁎ College of Chemistry and Environmental Engineering, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen 518060, Guangdong, China College of Chemistry and Environmental Engineering Shenzhen University Shenzhen Guangdong 518060 China College of Chemistry and Environmental Engineering, Shenzhen University, Shenzhen 518060, Guangdong, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract During discharge, Fe3Se4 interacts with LiPSs to form Li x FeS y . The change in the reaction pathway accelerates the reaction kinetics of the battery and induces three-dimensional deposition of Li2S, resulting in excellent rate performance. Although lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) exhibit high theoretical energy density, their practical application is hindered by poor conductivity of the sulfur cathode, the shuttle effect, and the irreversible deposition of Li2S. To address these issues, a novel composite, using electrospinning technology, consisting of Fe3Se4 and porous nitrogen-doped carbon nanofibers was designed for the interlayer of LSBs. The porous carbon nanofiber structure facilitates the transport of ions and electrons, while the Fe3Se4 material adsorbs lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) and accelerates its catalytic conversion process. Furthermore, the Fe3Se4 material interacts with soluble LiPSs to generate a new polysulfide intermediate, Li x FeS y complex, which changes the electrochemical reaction pathway and facilitates the three-dimensional deposition of Li2S, enhancing the reversibility of LSBs. The designed LSB demonstrates a high specific capacity of 1529.6 mA h g−1 in the first cycle at 0.2 C. The rate performance is also excellent, maintaining an ultra-high specific capacity of 779.7 mA h g−1 at a high rate of 8 C. This investigation explores the mechanism of the interaction between the interlayer and LiPSs, and provides a new strategy to regulate the reaction kinetics and Li2S deposition in LSBs. Keywords Lithium-sulfur batteries Polysulfide intermediates Li2S electrodeposition Interlayers Electrostatic spinning Adsorption Catalysis 1 Introduction With the rapid development of the social economy and electrification, the demand for energy continues to increase. Lithium-ion batteries, commonly used in daily life, can no longer satisfy the burgeoning energy requirements [1]. Lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) have attracted extensive research due to their theoretical energy density of 2567 Wh kg−1. Furthermore, their low cost and environmentally friendly characteristics indicate significant commercialization potential [2]. However, the multiple electron transfer reactions in LSBs not only provide high specific energies, but also lead to complex conversion reaction processes. One of the most severe issues is the formation of highly soluble intermediate polysulfides during the multi-electron transfer process between S8 and Li. These soluble polysulfides can cross the separator, reaching the cathode side and reacting directly with the lithium metal. This reaction leads to irreversible capacity loss, known as the notorious “shuttle effect” [3]. Additionally, the low conductivity of insoluble products (S8, Li2S2, and Li2S) generated during the charge-discharge process can passivate the electrode surface, rendering a portion of the products inactive and unable to react further. This phenomenon leads to increased polarization and severe capacity loss at high rates [4,5]. To tackle these challenges, researchers have explored various modificatory methods, including electrolyte modification, cathode modification, separator modification [6], and the insertion of functional interlayers [7]. These modification strategies can usually take advantage of the strong adsorption and fast catalytic conversion of materials to lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) to mitigate the shuttle effect. However, LSBs encompass intricate electrochemical reaction mechanisms, and certain materials tend to exhibit unique interactions with LiPSs. Investigating these interaction mechanisms is beneficial to the design of improvement strategies for LSBs. In this regard, Zhang et al. examined the interaction between intermediate polysulfides and polymer binders in sulfur electrodes using in situ XAS and designed a polyethyleneimine (PEI) polymer as a polar binder for LSB applications [8]. The study demonstrated that the amino group in the PEI polymer forms robust electrostatic interactions with polysulfide intermediates, effectively mitigating the shuttle effect. Since LiPSs are soluble in the electrolyte, the polysulfide intermediate can also be modified by incorporating electrolyte additives. Fan et al. introduced quinone hydroquinone (QH) as a functional molecular binder (MB) in the electrolyte to copolymerize with polysulfides, forming -[MB-Li2S n ]-, a solid complex that exhibits enhanced stability when immobilized on the cathode surface and displays accelerated conversion kinetics [9]. In addition, some of the studies have shown that reversible chemical reactions occur between polysulfides and certain transition metal compounds, which makes their electrochemical reaction kinetics more favorable. A classic example is the study reported in 2015 by Nazar's group, which used MnO2 nanosheets as sulfur hosts for LSBs [10]. The research revealed that host MnO2 reacts with the initially formed LiPSs to generate surface-bound intermediate polythionate complexes. These complexes serve as anchoring and transfer mediators, inhibiting the dissolution of the polysulfides into the electrolyte and controlling the deposition of Li2S2 or Li2S. Recently, Hua et al. demonstrated that In2O3, as a catalyst, can enhance the sulfur reduction reaction (SRR) process. Moreover, at the end of discharge, In2O3 interacts with LiPSs to form LiInS2 [11]. This newly formed LiInS2 catalyst significantly reduces the energy barrier for the oxidation of Li2S to Li2S n and eventually to elemental sulfur, thereby promoting the sulfur evolution reaction (SER) and achieving a dynamic catalytic effect. In recent years, the utilization of interlayers in LSB systems has gained significance owing to the simple preparation method and excellent electrochemical performance of the interlayer material. The primary purpose of the interlayer is to retain soluble LiPSs on the cathode side through a combination of physical barriers and chemical adsorption. Additionally, the interlayer is beneficial to the rapid catalytic conversion of LiPSs and promotes their conversion to solid products, thus effectively mitigating the shuttle effect. Electrospinning is a simple and efficient technique for constructing carbon nanofiber composites as functional interlayers. The nanofiber can be designed by adjusting the precursors or subsequent procedures to improve the adsorption and catalytic conversion of LiPSs by the interlayer [12]. Presently, carbon nanofiber composites with CoSe [13], MnS [14], TiN [15], TiO2 [16], and Fe3C [17] have been prepared using electrospinning techniques for LSBs interlayers, yielding promising outcomes. Similarly, the investigation of the interaction between the interlayer material and LiPSs is attracted more and more attention of researchers. Currently, most researchers believe that the effect of interlayer materials on LSBs is mainly in the adsorption and catalytic effect on LiPSs, as well as having the effects of accelerating the migration of lithium ions [18–20]. It is important to note, however, that while the interlayer does not serve as a host for sulfur storage, it often accumulates Li2S and S8 on its surface after cycling, primarily due to its strong adsorption properties towards sulfur species [21,22]. Therefore, it is also important to investigate the deposition behavior of Li2S and S8 on the interlayer. Generally, three-dimensional deposition of Li2S and S8 offers better reversible performance compared to two-dimensional deposition, as it does not completely cover the conductive surface of the interlayer [23,24]. To regulate the three-dimensional deposition of Li2S, researchers have primarily focused on modifying the electrolyte by introducing a high donor number solvents [25,26] or redox mediators [27,28]. Additionally, a few studies have demonstrated that certain solid compounds can also facilitate the three-dimensional deposition of Li2S. For instance, Zeng et al. designed a Fe3C@foam carbon/S-carbon fiber cathode, which exhibited reversible three-dimensional deposition of Li2S on its fiber surface during cell cycling [24]. Although this study demonstrated that the unique three-dimensional porous structure of the Li2S cathode reduces the diffusion paths of ions and electrons and improves the electrochemical performance of LSBs. However, further studies are needed to understand the interaction mechanism between the interlayer and the polysulfide, as well as the process of three-dimensional Li2S deposition. In this study, we designed a composite of porous nitrogen-doped carbon nanofibers loaded with Fe3Se4 (Fe3Se4@PNCNFs) using electrospinning technique and heat treatment. This composite was employed as an interlayer in LSBs to enhance their electrochemical properties. The results indicate that Fe3Se4@PNCNFs exhibit strong adsorption and catalytic effects on LiPS intermediates generated during the charging and discharging of LSBs, thus retaining the LiPSs on the cathode side and mitigating the shuttle effect. Furthermore, the high electrical conductivity reduces interfacial impedance, accelerating the mobility of lithium ions. The interaction mechanism between LiPSs and interlayer materials was also investigated, and the results showed that Fe3Se4 could react with LiPSs, resulting in the formation of a novel polysulfide intermediate known as Li x FeS y . This intermediate promotes the 3D deposition of Li2S, thereby enhancing its reversibility and rate performance, thereby offering a novel approach for improving LSB performance. After assembling Fe3Se4@PNCNFs as an interlayer in LSBs, they not only exhibited favorable capacity retention at low currents densities, but also remarkably maintained ultra-high specific capacity at high currents densities under the influence of polysulfide intermediates. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of Fe3Se4@PNCNFs First, 3 mmol of FeSO4·7H2O (0.834 g), 0.8 g of polyacrylonitrile (PAN), and 0.8 g of polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) were dissolved in 10 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF). The solution was continuously stirred for 24 h and then transferred to a 20 mL syringe for electrostatic spinning. The electrostatic spinning machine had a positive voltage of 17.5 kV on the metal needle and a negative voltage of −0.5 kV on the receiver, with a distance of 15 cm between them. The precursor nanofibers, produced via electrospinning, were initially placed in a muffle furnace and pre-oxidized at 280 °C for 3 h. Subsequently, they were transferred to a tube furnace and calcined at 800 °C for 2 h under an argon gas atmosphere. In the final step, 300 mg of selenium powder was situated in an upstream porcelain boat within the tube furnace, while the nanofibers were positioned in a downstream porcelain boat. Calcination was performed at 500 °C for 3 h in a hydrogen/argon atmosphere, resulting in the synthesis of Fe3Se4@PNCNFs composites. The PNCNFs materials were synthesized using the same method, except that FeSO4·7H2O was not added to the spinning solution. 2.2 Preparation of S/CNT cathode material Sulfur/carbon nanotube (S/CNT) composites were chosen as LSB cathode materials for LSBs. Sublimated sulfur (S) and carbon nanotubes (CNT) were ground in a 4:1 ratio in a mortar, adding carbon disulfide until the mixture became homogeneous and the CS2 completely evaporated. The mixture was then placed in a sealed bottle filled with inert gas and heated to 155 °C for 12 h, yielding the final S/CNT composite. The pre-prepared S/CNT, Ketjen black (KB), and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) were thoroughly mixed in N-Methylpyrrolidone (NMP) using a planetary slurry stirrer, forming a positive slurry that was evenly coated on aluminum foil. The S/CNT composite was dried under vacuum at 60 °C for 24 h and subsequently cut into 12 mm diameter electrode sheets using a manual puncher. The sulfur loading density of the cathode was 1.2 mg cm−2, while for the cathode used in the pouch battery, it was 3 mg cm−2. 2.3 Battery assembly CR2032 type coin cells were assembled in an argon-filled glovebox, utilizing an S/CNT electrode (diameter = 12 mm; Sulfur loading≈1.35 mg) as the positive electrode, Celgard 2400 microporous polypropylene film as the separator, and lithium (15 mm × 0.5 mm) as the counter electrode. The interlayer material was cut into 17 mm diameter discs and positioned between the polyethylene separator and the cathode. The electrolyte comprised 1.0 M lithium bis-trifluoromethanesulphonylimide (LiTFSI) dissolved in 1,3-dioxolane and 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DOL:DME, 1:1 vol) with 1.0 wt% LiNO3 additive. Approximately 80 µL of electrolyte was added to each cell. Symmetric cells were also assembled in an argon-filled glovebox using CR2032 type coin cells, with 14 mm diameter interlayer material discs placed on both sides of the separator as the positive and negative electrodes. Subsequently, 30 µL of the prepared 0.1 M Li2S6 solution (DME/DOL as solvent, containing 1 M LiTFSI) was added dropwise to each side of the positive and negative electrodes. The assembly of the pouch batteries was carried out in an argon-filled glove box. The prepared S/CNT cathode, interlayer material, separator, and lithium foil were cut into rectangular shapes of 2 cm × 4 cm, 2.5 cm × 4.5 cm, 3 cm × 5 cm, and 2.5 cm × 4.5 cm, respectively, which were assembled and heat-sealed with aluminum-plastic film in the order of Fig. S1. The electrolyte sulfur ratio (E/S) of a pouch battery was about 8 µL mg−1. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements The constant-current charge/discharge tests in this study were conducted using the LAND CT2001A and NEWARE CT-4008 battery test systems, with voltages ranging between 1.8 and 2.8 V. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) experiments (1.8–2.8 V) and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) experiments (105–0.01 Hz) were analyzed using an Ivium-n-Stat electrochemical workstation. PITT testing was performed on NEWARE CT-4008 battery test systems. Batteries were charged and discharged at 5 mV intervals with a cutoff current of C/200. Furthermore, the characteristic curves of Li2S deposition, as demonstrated by the PITT data, were comparatively analyzed using the Scharifker-Hills (SH) model and the Bewick-Fleischman-Thirsk (BFT) model [29]. The SH model describes 3D instantaneous (3DI) nucleation and 3D progressive (3DP) nucleation as two types of deposition, with their respective mathematical expressions presented in Eqs. (1) and (2). (1) 3 D I : I I m = 1.9542 t / t m 0.5 1 - e x p − 1.2564 t t m (2) 3 D P : I I m = 1.2254 t / t m 0.5 1 - e x p − 2.3367 t t m 2 In contrast, the BFT model describes two deposition methods: 2D instantaneous nucleation (2DI) and 2D progressive nucleation (2DP). Their mathematical expressions are shown in Eqs. (3) and (4) as follows. (3) 2 D I : I I m = t t m e x p 1 2 1 - t t m 2 (4) 2 D P : I I m = t t m 2 e x p 2 3 1 - t t m 3 2.5 Materials characterization The high-resolution morphology of the products was analyzed using field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, JSM-7800F, 10 kV, Japan). Field emission transmission electron microscopy (FETEM, JEOLF200 and TEAM Octane Plus, X-Max 80, 200–300 kV, Japan) was employed to observe the samples at the nanometer scale and to conduct energy dispersive analysis of X-ray (EDAX). The crystal structure of the material was confirmed by X-ray diffractometry (XRD, PANalytical Empyrean, The Netherlands) operating at 45 kV and 40 mA with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). The chemical states and elements present in the samples were identified using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific K-Alpha+, UK), with Ag K α radiation source, operating voltage of 15 kV, and power of 300 W. Raman spectroscopy (Raman Spectroscopy, Renishaw inVia, UK) was utilized to determine the degree of graphitization of the prepared carbon fibers and the material composition, with an excitation wavelength of 532 nm and range of 0–3000 cm−1. The solution composition was analyzed using a UV-Vis spectrophotometer (UV-Vis, DR600, USA). The liquid phase composition of Fe3Se4@PNCNFs after reaction with Li2S6 solution was quantified using an inductively Inductive Coupled Plasma Emission Spectrometer (ICP, Avio 200, USA). In-situ XRD measurements were characterized using an in-situ X-ray diffractometer (In-situ XRD, PANalytical Empyrean, The Netherlands) connected to a LAND CT2001A cell test system. The S/CNT material was coated on a beryllium sheet as the positive electrode with a sulfur loading of 3 mg, and a Swagelok cell was assembled by adding an interlayer and performing charge/discharge cycles at a current density of 0.1 C in the operating voltage range of 1.8–2.8 V. The detection conditions were set at a scan rate of 0.06 s−1 with a 2θ range of 15° to 60° and a step size of 0.02°. 2.6 First-principle calculations (DFT) In this study, density-functional theory (DFT) with spin polarization calculations was performed in the Vienna Ab Initio Simulation Package (VASP) code. Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) was used to describe the electron exchange correlation energy. The projection-enhanced wave (PAW) method was used to describe the ionic core. The computed 2 × 2 supercell structures were periodic boundary conditions in the x and y directions. There is a 15 Å vacuum separation between the structure and its neighbors in the z-direction. A plane wave basis set was used with an energy cutoff of 450 eV. K-points were set to 2 × 2 × 1 for structure optimization and energy calculations. All calculations were performed until the forces and energies converged to less than 0.02 eV Å−1 and 10−5 eV. The Li2S, Li2S2, Li2S4, Li2S6, Li2S8, and S8 adsorption process was also investigated with DFT calculations to obtain the adsorption energy (ΔE ads), and using the following formula. (5) Δ E ads = E base - ads - ( E base + E ads ) where E base−ads, E base, and E ads represented the total energy of base-adsorption species, base, and adsorption species, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of Fe3Se4@PNCNFs Fig. 1 schematically demonstrates the preparation process of the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs composite. Initially, FeSO4·7H2O, polyacrylonitrile (PAN), and polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) were initially dissolved in N,N-dimethylformamide (NMP) to form the spinning solution. Subsequently, the nanofiber membrane precursors were produced through (I) electrostatic spinning, followed by heat treatment involving (II) pre-oxidation, (III) calcination, and (IV) selenization in three sequential steps, yielding the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs composites. Fig. S2 presents the optical images of spun fiber membranes at each processing stage. Throughout the fabrication, PAN spun fiber is carbonized, forming carbon nanofibers during heat treatment. The nitrile group generates nitrogen doping in the carbon fiber post-treatment. Moreover, PMMA decomposes to create pores under pre-oxidation conditions at 280 °C [30], while the metallic iron sources form metallic selenides and remain embedded in the carbon nanofibers during selenization at 500 °C. The crystal structures and chemical compositions of the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs and PNCNFs materials were investigated using X-ray diffraction (XRD). As depicted in Fig. 2 (a), the diffraction peaks of Fe3Se4@PNCNFs align with the standard spectrum of monoclinic Fe3Se4 (PDF#04-007-8080), confirming the successful synthesis of the compounds. Moreover, both Fe3Se4@PNCNFs and PNCNFs exhibit a broad peak at approximately 25°, attributable to the characteristic peak of amorphous carbon [31]. The chemical composition of the compounds was further confirmed through Raman spectroscopy. As illustrated in Fig. 2(b), the Raman spectrum of Fe3Se4 corresponds to that reported in a previous study [32]. Overall, Fe3Se4 exhibits Raman-activated vibrations, including 6Ag and 3Bg modes of Fe–Se bond vibrations at 221 and 288 cm−1, respectively. The Raman peaks at 405 and 605 cm−1 correspond to overtone frequency vibrations at 221 cm−1, while the peak at 489 cm−1 is a combination mode of Fe-Se vibrations observed at 221 and 288 cm−1. Furthermore, the Raman spectra of all materials display two vibrations at approximately 1360 cm−1 (D band) and 1580 cm−1 (G band), indicating the presence of amorphous carbon. The D band signifies defects in carbon atom crystals, while the G band represents in-plane stretching vibrations of carbon atom sp 2 hybridization. By calculating the intensity ratio between the D band and the G band, the number of defects in carbon atoms within the material can be determined. The I(D)/I(G) of Fe3Se4@PNCNFs is 1.033, greater than that of PNCNFs at 0.937. An increase in defects in carbon fiber material enhances electron transport in the battery, potentially improving its rate performance. The surface chemical phases and composition of the material were analyzed using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements. The high-resolution C 1s spectrum presented in Fig. S3(a) displays three characteristic peaks for C=O (288.4 eV), C–N (286.1 eV), and sp 2 hybridized carbon (C–C, 284.8 eV).[33] The high-resolution N 1s spectrum in Fig. S3(b) exhibits three peaks for pyridinic-N (398.2 eV), pyrrolic-N (400.1 eV), and graphitic-N (401.1 eV), signifying successful nitrogen doping in carbon nanofibers [34]. The high-resolution Fe 2p spectrum (Fig. 2c) comprises two main peaks corresponding to Fe 2p 3/2 (710.7 eV) and Fe 2p 1/2 (724.0 eV), resulting from spin-orbit splitting [35,36]. Finally, the high-resolution Se 3d spectrum depicted in Fig. S3(c) reveals two main peaks for Se 3d 5/2 (55.2 eV) and Se 3d 3/2 (56.0 eV). Additionally, the peak located at 58.8 eV can be attributed to the Se–O bond, resulting from the surface oxidation of selenium during selenization and typically observed in selenium compounds [37]. The surface morphology and microstructure of Fe3Se4@PNCNFs materials were investigated using field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). As depicted in Fig. 2(d), the interlayer material is composed of nanofibers with diameters ranging from 0.5 to 1 μm, and its fibers are adorned with numerous Fe3Se4 particles of varying sizes. Moreover, the inset of Fig. 2(d) reveals that the interior of the carbon nanofibers possesses an abundant pore structure, which is also clearly observable in the transmission image of Fig. 2(e). According to prior studies, the formation of these pore channels results from the gradual pyrolysis and volatilization of PMMA during the pre-oxidation process [30,38,39]. This can be observed in Fig. S4, which shows that the FeSO4@PAN/PMMA precursors display pore structures after pre-oxidation. To substantiate this phenomenon, PMMA-free fibers were prepared and conducted thermogravimetric tests for comparison. As illustrated in Fig. S5, the fibers with added PMMA lost 49.03% of mass after 3 h of exposure at 280 °C in air, whereas the pure PAN fibers only lost 16.15%. This result implies that PMMA volatilization during the pre-oxidation process causes the fibers to develop this porous structure, and the FESEM image in Fig. S6 also demonstrates that the PMMA-added material exhibits a rougher texture and higher pore density after pre-oxidation. To further investigate this, BET tests were performed on various samples (Fig. S7). The results show that the PMMA-added fibers possess a higher specific surface area, and the pore size distribution ranged predominantly between 10–50 nm. This unique porous structure provides increased ion-binding sites and electron transfer pathways, thereby enhancing the internal reaction kinetics of LSBs. Meanwhile, the porous structure enables the fibers to interact more thoroughly with the electrolyte, as corroborated by the contact angle test in Fig. S8. The exceptional electrolyte wettability of this interlayer material positively contributes to the mass transfer within the battery [40]. The particles located on the nanofibers were examined at a high magnification using TEM. As shown in Fig. 2(f), the outer layers of the particles are encased in carbon and exhibit prominent lattice stripes with measured lattice spacings of 0.270 and 0.208 nm, which can be ascribed to the (1 1 1) and (3 1 1) crystallographic planes of Fe3Se4, respectively. The SAED pattern shown in Fig. 2(g) exhibits polycrystalline features with uniform diffraction rings, indicating the high crystallinity of the Fe3Se4 material. Moreover, the three distinct diffraction rings correspond to the three main crystal planes (1 1 1), (3 1 1) and (−6 0 3) of the Fe3Se4 material, respectively. The elemental mapping of Fe3Se4@PNCNFs is presented in Fig. 2(h) and Fig. S9. The distribution of carbon, nitrogen, iron, and selenium elements in the prepared Fe3Se4@PNCNFs composites are uniformly distributed, indicating that the Fe3Se4 particles are uniformly dispersed throughout the one-dimensional nitrogen-doped carbon fibers. In particular, due to the abundance of nitrogen-containing functional groups in polyacrylonitrile (PAN) fibers, the energy spectrum after pyrolysis clearly displays that the nitrogen elements are uniformly distributed on the carbon fibers, signifying successful nitrogen doping. The crystal structure of Fe3Se4 was investigated, as illustrated in the schematic crystal structure in Fig. 2(i). The synthesized Fe3Se4 exhibits a monoclinic crystal system structure, belonging to the C2/m space group. According to previous reports [41], the Fe3Se4 structure comprises an arrangement of FeSe2-Fe-FeSe2, analogous to Ta embedded in the Ta7S12 phase [42]. In this arrangement, Fe atoms are periodically embedded within the van der Waals gaps of the layered FeSe2. The embedded Fe atom exhibits high reactivity and also optimizes the electronic structure of the crystal, resulting in enhanced electrical conductivity [43]. At present, the d-band and p-band center models are extensively employed to ascertain the adsorption and catalytic energy barriers in LSB materials [44]. Therefore, the partial density of states (PDOS) for Fe3Se4 and nitrogen-doped nanofibers was calculated by density functional theory. As depicted in Fig. 2(j) and Fig. S10, the p-band center of the Fe3Se4 material is situated closer to the Fermi energy level in comparison to nitrogen-doped carbon nanofibers. Meanwhile, the gap between the Fe and Se p-band centers is reduced, facilitating electron transfer and the subsequent conversion of LiPSs. Consequently, Fe3Se4 materials have the potential to achieve high rate performance and power density. 3.2 Electrochemical performance of Fe3Se4@PNCNFs as an interlayer in LSBs The Fe3Se4@PNCNFs was integrated into a lithium-sulfur cell for a series of electrochemical tests. The performance of this cell was compared to those containing a PNCNFs interlayer and those without an interlayer. Fig. 3 (a) displays the cycling performance of the cell at 0.2 C (1 C = 1675 mA g−1). As illustrated in the Figure, the cell utilizing Fe3Se4@PNCNFs material as the interlayer exhibits a high initial discharge specific capacity of 1529.6 mA h g−1 and maintains 997.3 mA h g−1 after 150 cycles, significantly surpassing the performance of cells with PNCNFs and without interlayer. Furthermore, the charge-discharge curve (Fig. 3b) demonstrates that the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs material exhibits the lowest polarization voltage Δ V, and a high Q H/Q L (the ratio of high- and low-plateau capacities) value of 2.84, which is notably higher than the 2.19 for the cell with a PNCNFs interlayer and 1.93 for the cell without interlayer. These findings indicate that the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs material enhances the kinetics of the redox reaction in the LSBs [45]. Upon analyzing the amplified charge–discharge curve (Fig. 3c), it becomes evident that the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs material exhibits the lowest nucleation overpotential and dissolution overpotential, suggesting that Li2S is more easily deposited and dissolved on the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs material [46]. The rate performance of the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs was subsequently evaluated, as depicted in Fig. 3(d). At a high current density of 8C, the material maintains an exceptional specific capacity of 779.7 mA h g−1 and retains a specific capacity of 1481.4 mA h g−1 (equivalent to 96.8% of its initial value) after returning to 0.2 C, demonstrating high reversibility and fast redox kinetics. Correlating charge and discharge curves were plotted for various current densities (Fig. 3e and Fig. S11). Fe3Se4@PNCNFs-based cells consistently maintain two distinct voltage plateaus below 5 C. However, as the current density increases, polarization rises, resulting in capacity reduction, and the plateau becomes less distinct at 8 C, despite maintaining a high specific capacity. In contrast, other cells, particularly those lacking an interlayer, suffer from severe capacity decline and substantial polarization as the current density increases. It is worth mentioning that, besides the rate performance test, a direct cycle test of the battery was conducted at high current density without low current activation, as depicted in Fig. 3(f). Once more, Fe3Se4@PNCNFs maintains exceptionally high discharge-specific capacities after 150 cycles at rates of 1 C, 2 C, 3 C, and 4 C, with respective capacities of 987.2, 903.4, 861.9, 694.8 mA h g, and 694.8 mA h g−1. These results indicate that the role of Fe3Se4@PNCNFs as an interlayer in LSBs promotes rapid and efficient ion and electron transfer at the electrode interface, enabling LSBs to sustain high capacities at high current densities. The long-cycle stability of batteries with various interlayers was evaluated by initially conducting three charge/discharge cycles at 0.2 C to achieve full activation, and then increasing the current density to 1 C for 500 charge/discharge cycles (Fig. 3g). The outcomes reveal that batteries without interlayers and those with PNCNFs experience significant decay at 1 C current density, with discharge capacities of 43.5 and 136.3 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles, respectively. The corresponding decay rates were 0.184% and 0.174% per cycle. In contrast, the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs cell demonstrates remarkable cycling stability, maintaining a high specific capacity of 591.8 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles and a capacity decay rate of merely 0.074% per cycle, the performance considerably superior to both cells of PNCNFs and cells without interlayers. Additionally, the self-discharge behavior of various batteries was assessed. Self-discharge test results (Fig. 3h) reveal that cells without interlayers and those with PNCNFs interlayers experience a dramatic decline in capacity upon recharging and discharging following a five-day resting period, retaining only 30.6% and 71.4% of their pre-resting capacity, respectively. In contrast, cells incorporating Fe3Se4@PNCNFs interlayers retain 96.6% of their pre-resting initial discharge-specific capacity after resting, demonstrating minimal self-discharge. These findings indicate that the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs interlayer effectively adsorbs and stores LiPSs, constraining the loss of sulfur species during battery stasis and thus significantly mitigating self-discharge behavior [47]. Ultimately, to exhibit the practical application potential of the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs interlayer material, it was assembled into a flexible pouch cell for evaluation. The assembled flexible pouch cell featured a sulfur surface loading rate of approximately 3 mg cm−2 and an electrolyte/sulfur ratio (E/S) of 8 μL mg−1. At a current density of 0.1 C (Fig. 3i), the initial cycle of the cell yielded a discharge-specific capacity of 870.8 mA h g−1 and an average discharge voltage of 2.045 V (Fig. S12). After 40 charge/discharge cycles, the cell retained a capacity of 677.47 mA h g−1, corresponding to a 77.8% capacity retention rate. A bending test performed on the flexible pouch cell (Fig. S13) demonstrates the capacity of the cell to maintain stable voltage and current under various bending conditions, enabling the LED to emit light. This result reveals the potential of the material in flexible device applications. 3.3 Effect of Fe3Se4@PNCNFs on soluble LiPSs Prior battery performance test data reveal that the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs material significantly enhances the cycling performance of LSBs while maintaining high specific capacity at elevated current densities. In order to explore the reason of the excellent electrochemical performance of Fe3Se4@PNCNFs, a series of tests was further carried out. As depicted in Fig. 4 (a), all CV curves exhibit one oxidation peak and two reduction peaks, corresponding to their charge and discharge curves. The comparison reveals that the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs exhibits the highest current peak and the largest peak area, indicating its ability as an interlayer to accelerate the electrochemical redox reaction and achieve the highest charge/discharge specific capacity. Furthermore, the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs demonstrates the lowest oxidation peak voltage and the highest reduction peak voltage, signifying minimal polarization and enhanced battery reaction kinetics. Each peak in the CV curve was individually fitted, and its Tafel slope was analyzed. As illustrated in Figs. 4(b) and S14, the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs exhibits the smallest Tafel slope at all three peak positions, implying a faster redox kinetic process and an accelerated catalytic conversion of LiPSs, thereby reducing the shuttle effect [45]. To further evaluate the catalytic conversion performance of the interlayer for LiPSs, a symmetric cell was assembled and tested. The schematic representation of the symmetric cell assembly can be found in Fig. S15. Cyclic voltammetric tests were performed on the symmetric cell in the voltage range of −0.8 to 0.8 V with a sweep rate of 50 mV s−1 (Fig. S16) and 0.5 mV s−1 (Fig. 4c), respectively. The Fe3Se4@PNCNFs exhibits the highest response current in the CV at increased sweep speeds. Additionally, this material demonstrates a reduced polarization voltage at lower sweep rates, suggesting its strong electrocatalytic activity. In addition to the catalytic performance of the material for LiPSs, in general, the strong adsorption capacity of the material for LiPSs can prevent them from reacting with the negative side through the separator, thereby reducing the loss of active material mass. To examine the adsorption performance of the interlayer on LiPSs, an adsorption visualization method was employed to compare the adsorption strength of Fe3Se4@PNCNFs and NCNFs. 5 mg of each interlayer material was added to 2.5 mL of Li2S8, Li2S6, and Li2S4 solutions and observed. As illustrated in Fig. 4(d) and Fig. S17, the Li2S8, Li2S6, and Li2S4 solutions containing Fe3Se4@PNCNFs became colorless and transparent after 16 h, whereas the color of solutions with PNCNFs remained relatively unchanged. This suggests a stronger adsorption capacity for LiPS solutions in comparison to PNCNFs materials. This strong adsorption capacity is also reflected in the FESEM observation of the separator material after cell cycling. After 20 cycles of the cell, the separator was removed, dried in a glove box, and subjected to FESEM and elemental mapping analyses on the central portion of its negative side. The results (Fig. 4e) reveal that the separator without the addition of an interlayer exhibits numerous fine LiPS particles on the negative side, indicating a pronounced shuttle effect within the cell. In contrast, the distribution of LiPS particles on the negative side of the separator with an added interlayer was reduced, with no particles detected on the negative side of the separator containing Fe3Se4@PNCNFs as the interlayer. The elemental mapping demonstrated the lowest sulfur content of 12.42%. These findings suggest that the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs material exhibits a robust adsorption effect on LiPSs, effectively preventing its migration across the separator during charge and discharge cycles, thereby enhancing the cycle stability of LSBs. The reasons for the high rate performance demonstrated by the LSBs in this study were investigated. Typically, rate performance is related to the lithium-ion mobility [48]. Therefore, EIS tests were performed to analyze the electrode process kinetics and interfacial reaction mechanisms within the cell (Fig. 4f). The test results were fitted with the equivalent circuit model presented in Fig. S18. The fitted outcomes of calculations (Fig. S19 and Table S1) reveal that the charge transfer resistance (R ct) significantly decreases when interlayer material is introduced, signifying that the incorporation of the interlayer contributes to rapid electron transfer and a faster electrochemical reaction rate [49]. However, the introduction of the interlayer also increases the resistance of surface film (R sf) within the cell. Nonetheless, the interfacial resistance of the cell with the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs material as the interlayer is considerably lower than the cell assembled with PNCNFs material, indicating that the highly conductive Fe3Se4 material greatly reduces the interfacial impedance between the interlayer and the anode. The sloping straight line in the low-frequency region represents the Warburg impedance, reflecting lithium-ion diffusion behavior. The lithium-ion diffusion coefficient, obtained from Table S1, demonstrates that the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs cell exhibits the highest diffusion coefficient. This suggests that the incorporation of Fe3Se4@PNCNFs promotes rapid transfer and reaction of lithium ions, thereby enhancing the electrochemical kinetics of LSBs. Additionally, CV tests were performed at different scan rates to evaluate the lithium-ion mobility (Fig. S20). Subsequently, a linear fit of the square root of each peak current against the scan rate for different CVs was executed, with fitting results presented in Fig. 4(g–i). Fe3Se4@PNCNFs material exhibits the steepest slope at each peak, confirming the highest lithium-ion mobility [50]. This finding reveals the reason why Fe3Se4@PNCNFs can maintain high capacity at large rates as an interlayer in LSBs. 3.4 Interaction between Fe3Se4@PNCNFs and LiPSs During the investigation of LiPSs adsorption visualization, a particular phenomenon caught our attention: although LiPSs was entirely adsorbed by the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs material after 16 h, signifying its robust adsorption capacity, the solution color of the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs material slightly intensified within one hour after introducing the LiPSs solution. This occurrence was most pronounced in highly concentrated Li2S6 solutions (Fig. S21). To further examine this phenomenon, 5 mg samples of both Fe3Se4@PNCNFs and PNCNFs were immersed in a 5 mM concentrated Li2S6 solution for 12 h. The optical display results are depicted in the inset of Fig. 5 (a). Upon addition of the Li2S6 solution, the color of PNCNFs exhibited little change, while the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs turned distinctly darker, appearing black. We speculate that this phenomenon results from the interaction between Fe3Se4 and polysulfides. This action mechanism might resemble the role of iron-based catalysts in H2S during the hydrodesulfurization process in traditional chemical industries [51,52]. However, the literature on this phenomenon in the LSB field is limited. Consequently, in subsequent research, we delved into this phenomenon to uncover the underlying action mechanism and its impact on the electrochemical performance of LSBs. To investigate the mechanism of action, the liquid supernatant after 12 h of adsorption obtained was filtered and subjected to UV-Vis spectroscopy test (Fig. 5a). Due to the presence of Li2S6, the blank and Li2S6-PNCNFs samples exhibited a strong absorption peak near 412 nm, which was weakened due to the adsorption of PNCNFs on Li2S6. This absorption peak disappeared after the addition of Fe3Se4@PNCNFs, and two absorption peaks appeared at 370 and 445 nm, where the appearance of iron-sulfur compounds has been reported in the literature [53–55]. The supernatant was digested and tested by ICP (Fig. 5b), and the contents of Li, S, Fe, and Se elements were detected. Se elements were not characterized in any samples, and 1.52% Fe elements were detected in the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs sample, which indicates that Fe elements in Fe3Se4 react with LiPSs in small amounts. Meanwhile, the Raman spectral results of the supernatant are shown in Fig. 5(c), where the characteristic peaks of LiPSs at 407, 454, 499, and 531 cm−1 are weakened and new peaks are present for Fe3Se4@PNCNFs compared to the other two samples. Specifically, the peaks at 207 and 292 cm−1 are the A1g and B1g vibrational modes of tetragonal thionite mackinawite [56,57], and the two peaks at 251 and 322 cm−1 can be attributed to Fe3+-containing tetragonal thionite mackinawite [58]. Besides, the characteristic Raman peak of pyrite at 377 cm−1 was revealed [59]. The appearance of these new peaks suggests that Fe3Se4 reacts with LiPSs to form complexes Li x FeS y , and it is worth mentioning that these Li x FeS y appear as colloidal nanoparticles in the electrolyte, thus showing solution darkening rather than precipitation formation in the previous optical images [60]. To further confirm the formation of Li x FeS y , the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs material, after Li2S6 adsorption, was dried and subjected to XPS tests under vacuum. The results are displayed in Fig. 5(d and e). Compared to the pre-adsorption sample, the XPS of the adsorbed sample exhibited new peaks at 708.28 and 54.03 eV, attributable to Fe–S bonds [61]. The Fe–S bonding is also evident in the Se 3d spectrum at 54.0 eV [62]. Additionally, the characteristic peaks of Se 3d 5/2 and Se 3d 3/2 at 56.0 and 55.2 eV shifted to lower energy by 0.2 eV. This change in peak position is ascribed to the loss of Fe atoms in Fe3Se4, which increases the outer electron density of Se atoms. The aforementioned experiments demonstrate that the synthesized Fe3Se4@PNCNFs can directly interact with LiPSs, forming the complex Li x FeS y during the battery cycle. The reaction pathway within the cell is depicted schematically in Fig. 5(f), and a detailed exploration of this pathway will be presented in Section 2.4. During the discharge process, the sulfur cathode is initially reduced to soluble LiPSs and dissolved in the electrolyte. At this stage, the soluble LiPSs come into contact with Fe3Se4 and react to form small amounts of Li x FeS y species. As the reaction progresses, the LiPSs and newly generated Li x FeS y species continue to be reduced to the final product Li2S and deposited. It is evident that the reaction pathway of the lithium-sulfur cell is altered due to the formation of Li x FeS y species. We consider that this change is advantageous for the overall reaction kinetics and significantly improves the performance of LSBs when Fe3Se4@PNCNFs is used as an interlayer within the cell. The interaction between Li2S6 and Fe3Se4 (1 1 1) crystalline facet has been analyzed using density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Results after configuration optimization (Fig. S22) demonstrate that the Li2S6 structure readily forms bonds with Fe3Se4, indicating high reactivity between them. Through the construction of 3D differential charge diagrams (Fig. 5g) and 2D charge diagrams (Fig. 5h and i) for Fe, Se, Li, and S atoms, a numerous electron can be observed concentrated between Fe and S atoms, suggesting a strong interaction and an electron shift from Fe to S atoms. Additionally, the electron cloud at Se atoms diminished, implying a weakened interaction force between Fe and Se and facilitating the dissolution of Fe atoms from the surface. Moreover, the projected density of states (PDOS) results revealed a significant overlap between the d orbitals of Fe and the p orbitals of S at the −6 to −10 eV energy level. This more negative electron energy region indicates increased stability of the interaction, further supporting the facile formation of Li x FeS y complexes upon the combination of Fe3Se4 and LiPSs. 3.5 Effect of Fe3Se4@PNCNFs materials on Li2S deposition LSBs have a complex interconversion between LiPS in the charge and discharge processes. To examine the impact of the interlayer on this process, an adsorption model was developed (Fig. S23), and the stepwise disproportionation products (S8, Li2S8, Li2S6, Li2S4, Li2S2, and Li2S) of the Fe3Se4 and PNCNFs throughout the discharge process, as well as the free energy and adsorption energies between them, were calculated by using density functional theory (DFT). As illustrated in Fig. 6 (a), the Gibbs free energy variation calculations demonstrated that the required free energy for LiPS conversion on the Fe3Se4 material is lower at every step compared to the PNCNFs material. Notably, the reduction of Li2S4 to Li2S2/Li2S on PNCNFs exhibits a considerable positive free energy change (0.67 and 0.27 eV), with the largest energy change occurring during the liquid-solid conversion reaction of Li2S4 to Li2S2, which is the rate-determining step of the entire discharge process. Conversely, the same transformation on the Fe3Se4 surface displays a larger negative free energy change (−0.42 and −3.12 eV), suggesting that LiPS reduction is more thermodynamically favorable on the Fe3Se4 surface. This enables a rapid conversion of liquid LiPSs to solid Li2S2 and Li2S during the discharge process, thus minimizing the shuttle effect [45]. Moreover, as depicted in Fig. 6(b), the calculated adsorption energies of LiPSs on the Fe3Se4 surface are consistently higher than those on PNCNFs, which is consistent with the visualized adsorption results. The deposition behavior of Li2S is also crucial in determining the performance of LSBs. The DFT calculations reveal favorable thermodynamics and high adsorption energy of LiPSs on Fe3Se4 material during the final solid-liquid conversion stage. Therefore, the effect of the addition of the interlayer on Li2S deposition was explored. An in situ XRD test was initially performed, with the results displayed in Fig. 6(c and e). The XRD peak of α-S8 is observed to gradually decrease and eventually vanish at the onset of the discharge phase during the charging and discharging process of the LSB, corresponding to the conversion of α-S8 into soluble LiPSs. At the conclusion of the discharge phase, a broad XRD peak emerges near 26.9°, which corresponds to the (1 1 1) crystal plane of the Li2S compound (JCPDS 023-0369). This suggests that soluble LiPSs transforms into insoluble Li2S and accumulates on the cathode side at this stage. As charging proceeds, the peaks of Li2S gradually disappear, while a new set of peaks appears near 23.4°, 23.6°, 24.1°, 24.6°, 25.26°, 26.0°, 26.8°, and 28.35° at the end of the charging phase, which can be attributed to β-S8 (JCPDS 071-0137), consistent with previous reports [63]. Comparing Fe3Se4@PNCNFs and PNCNFs as interlayers, it is evident from the in situ XRD plot that the peaks of Li2S and β-S8 emerge earlier and are more pronounced with Fe3Se4@PNCNFs as an interlayer. Specifically, batteries with Fe3Se4@PNCNFs and PNCNFs as interlayers display the characteristic peaks of Li2S at discharge depths of 55.08% and 64.66%, respectively, and these peaks completely vanish at charging depths of 57.58% and 54.08%, meanwhile, the peaks of β-S8 appear at charging depths of 77.36% and 84.25%. The introduction of Fe3Se4 material suggests an enhancement in the reaction kinetics of LSBs, expediting the conversion of soluble LiPSs into Li2S and β-S8 during the discharge and charging processes, respectively. Consequently, soluble LiPSs are present in the battery for a reduced duration, diminishing its shuttle effect and ultimately decreasing the decay of LSBs during charge and discharge. To examine the influence of Fe3Se4 material on Li2S deposition, we disassembled the cell after cycling within a glove box, cleaned the interlayer material using 1,2-dimethoxyethane, and vacuum-dried it for FESEM analysis. The adsorption of Fe3Se4 material, as well as PNCNFs material on sulfur and LiPSs, results in the deposition of Li2S and β-S8 onto the fiber material at the conclusion of charging and discharging. Comparatively, electron micrographs (Fig. 6f and Fig. S24) reveal more deposits on the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs material following charging and discharging, suggesting that Fe3Se4 exhibits stronger adsorption to LiPSs. Notably, the Li2S was deposited onto the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs material in a sponge-like 3D configuration after the discharge process. This 3D porous structure of active Li2S not only exposes and sustains more active sites in the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs material but also shortens the ion/electron diffusion path and preserves its high conductivity, ensuring that the interlayer material remains unpassivated [64,65]. Conversely, at the end of charging, a dense and thick layer of β-S8 deposits on the PNCNFs material (Figs. 6d and Fig. S25), causing this interlayer to gradually deactivate during the cycling process. The spike-like, three-dimensional growth of β-S8 on Fe3Se4@PNCNFs material, which provides a greater reactive area, considerably improves the utilization of sulfur species and reduces energy loss in LSBs during cycling. The PITT test has been extensively employed to examine the deposition behavior of LSBs [66]. Owing to the distinct deposition morphology following charge and discharge cycles, PITT tests were also performed to scrutinize the LiPS deposition behavior during the reaction (Fig. 7 a and Fig. S26). The assembled cell commences at 2.3 V, with the working electrode potential decreasing in increments of 5 mV each time the current declines to the cutoff current, which corresponds to the C/200 rate. At high voltages, the current exhibits a monotonic decline at each stage, primarily due to the lack of a phase transition process, just the reduction of soluble polysulfides to lower-order soluble polysulfides. Upon reaching a constant voltage of 2.135 V, the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs material achieves its nucleation potential. At this stage, Li2S nuclei form and expand on the anode side, resulting in an increase in current. Nevertheless, upon reaching the peak, charge transfer is impeded by the nuclei's collision and the passivation of surface electron-insulating sulfides, consequently causing current decay [66]. Comparatively, the nucleation potentials of cells assembled with PNCNFs materials and cells without added interlayers are 10 and 55 mV lower, respectively, indicating that Fe3Se4 materials exhibit stronger binding to Li2S and superior sulfur reaction kinetics. Unlike the PNCNFs, the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs still shows a current peak at 2.110 V and contributes a higher specific capacity of 160.59 mA h g−1 at this voltage. This is not reported in other literature and we consider that this is a phase transition process where a small amount of Li x FeS y decomposes to form Li2S. Two classical electrochemical nucleation models, the BFT model and the SH model, were fitted to the current peak [29]. The fitted results (Fig. 7b and c and Fig. S27) show that the current curves at 2.135 V for Fe3Se4@PNCNFs cells, at 2.125 V for PNCNFs cells, and at 2.080 V for cells without interlayer materials (Fig. 7c) are consistent with the 2D nucleation model. Nevertheless, the current profile of Fe3Se4@PNCNFs at 2.110 V aligns with the 3D nucleation model, and the analysis of in situ XRD (Fig. S28), ex situ XPS (Fig. S29), and Section 2.3 suggests that Fe3Se4 reacts with LiPSs to form complex Li x FeS y species, ultimately resulting in 3D Li2S deposition at the end of the discharge. This observation is in accordance with the preceding electron microscopy data. In addition, in the PITT test for charging (Fig. S30), the Li2S dissociation potential of the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs material is at 2.290 V, which is lower than that of the PNCNFs material at 2.315 and 2.350 V without the addition of an interlayer, indicating that the introduction of Fe3Se4 can promote the reversible conversion of the discharge product Li2S, which give the battery better cycling stability. To confirm that the deposition of Fe3Se4@PNCNFs cells at 2.110 V originates from the decomposition of Li x FeS y , a PITT test was performed by incorporating iron acetylacetonate into the electrolyte of PNCNFs cells (Fig. 7d). Due to the presence of iron ions in the electrolyte, during the PITT test, the dissolved LiPSs rapidly react with iron ions to form the Li x FeS y compound. This compound is subsequently reduced to Li2S at 2.105 V and deposited on the interlayer material. The fitting of the deposition curve (Fig. 7e) at this point displays a strong agreement with the 3D instantaneous (3DI) nucleation model. Consequently, this finding also substantiates that the second deposition of Li2S on Fe3Se4@PNCNFs cells involves the reduction of Li x FeS y to Li2S. For the PNCNFs battery with the addition of iron acetylacetonate, a charge/discharge cycle test was also conducted, revealing (Fig. S31) that the charge/discharge curves maintained two plateaus analogous to those of the LSBs. This suggests that the introduction of iron ions did not alter the reaction pathway. However, the complexation of iron ions with LiPSs to form intermediates resulted in a low discharge plateau and a high charge plateau. Notably, our analysis of the nucleation overpotential of the charge–discharge curves (Fig. S31c and d) demonstrates that the introduction of iron ions causes remarkably low overpotential for Li2S deposition and dissolution. This suggests that the Li x FeS y intermediate facilitates the deposition and dissolution of Li2S, which is consistent with the previous experimental results and interpretations. As different current densities have a large effect on the deposition of Li2S [67], the effect of 3D deposition behavior at high current densities was investigated by electrochemical testing of interlayer materials. As depicted in Fig. 7(f), the cell was initially discharged at a low rate of 0.2 C for 3 h. By this time, the high-order LiPSs within the cell had primarily been converted to low-order LiPSs, and Li2S formation on the interlayer had commenced. Subsequently, the current density was increased to 1 C and continued until the cut-off voltage of 1.8 V was reached. The test results reveal an obvious voltage drop upon increasing the current density to 1 C. However, the voltage decline for the cell assembled with Fe3Se4 material is smaller, indicating a smaller polarization. Moreover, cells incorporating Fe3Se4 materials still deliver a specific capacity of 677.6 mA h g−1 at 1 C, significantly higher than the 393.5 mA h g−1 achieved with PNCNFs. This suggests that Fe3Se4 materials enable more efficient LiPS conversion and deposition at larger rates. Additionally, Li2S4 solution was prepared and directly introduced it as a sulfur source into the cell by dropwise addition to the positive electrode. In the discharged state, the subsequent reaction equations of the Li2S4 solution will proceed as shown below in Eqs. (6) and (7). (6) L i 2 S 4 + 2 L i + + 2 e - → 2 L i 2 S 2 (7) L i 2 S 2 + 2 L i + + 2 e - → 2 L i 2 S After the cell is assembled, a current density of 0.2C is applied and it is discharge to a cut-off voltage of 1.8 V. During which Li2S4 would undergo a solid–liquid reaction to form Li2S2 and continue the solid-solid reaction to produce Li2S deposition. The test results, presented in Fig. 7(g), demonstrate that the cell with Fe3Se4 material as the interlayer can generate a specific capacity of 554.8 mA h g−1, which is considerably higher than the 319.5 mA h g−1 achieved with PNCNFs. This suggests that the same mass of Li2S4 will result in more Li2S deposited on the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs interlayer. We attribute these phenomena to the optimization of Li2S deposition by the Fe3Se4 material, which prevents the complete coverage of active sites in the interlayer. Additionally, Li2S2 can be rapidly converted to Li2S on the Fe3Se4 surface, avoiding the loss of active material due to passivation caused by Li2S2 being covered by Li2S. To sum up, the exceptional electrochemical performance of the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs battery can be attributed to the following four factors (Fig. 7h): (1) The Fe3Se4@PNCNFs material exhibits strong adsorption and catalytic abilities toward the intermediate product LiPSs, enabling it to adsorb and anchor the LiPSs to the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs surface and catalytically accelerate its redox conversion, thereby reducing the shuttle effect; (2) the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs material significantly promotes the catalytic conversion between Li2S4, Li2S2, and Li2S, allowing for complete transformation without deactivation and capacity loss; (3) the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs material possesses high conductivity and lithium-ion transport rates, facilitating the rapid oxidation-reduction of poorly conductive S and Li2S; (4) Fe3Se4 reacts with LiPSs in small quantities to produce Li x FeS y , which is subsequently converted to Li2S for three-dimensional deposition. This process ensures that the active surface of the interlayer remains uncovered, allowing for ion and electron transport and promoting the reversible conversion between LiPSs and S8. 4 Conclusions In summary, Fe3Se4@PNCNFs composites were synthesized using a straightforward electrospinning method combined with heat treatment. The assembled cells containing Fe3Se4@PNCNFs composites retained a high specific capacity of 980.2 mA h g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.2 C, 591.8 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles at 1 C with a decay rate of 0.074% per cycle, and maintained an exceptional rate performance of 800.8 mA h g−1 at 4 C. The comprehensive analysis revealed that the Fe3Se4@PNCNFs composites exhibit high electrical conductivity and lithium-ion mobility, as well as robust adsorption and catalytic abilities for LiPSs. Notably, we observed an interaction between Fe3Se4 and LiPSs that has been overlooked by the majority of researchers. This interaction results in the generation of Li x FeS y polysulfide intermediates, which can significantly influence the deposition behavior of Li2S, despite the small reaction quantity. This deposition behavior facilitates the three-dimensional deposition of Li2S on the carbon fiber interlayer, thereby preserving high ion and electron transport capacity and significantly enhancing the cycle reversibility and rate performance of LSBs. This finding provides novel insights into the regulation of reaction kinetics and Li2S deposition in LSBs. Moreover, a crucial insight from this study is the need for researchers to focus on the interactions between interlayers or sulfur carriers and LiPSs, as well as the effects of these interactions on electrochemical behaviors, in order to offer enhanced guidance for the design and application of LSBs. coredata.dc:description: Although lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) exhibit high theoretical energy density, their practical application is hindered by poor conductivity of the sulfur cathode, the shuttle effect, and the irreversible deposition of Li2S. To address these issues, a novel composite, using electrospinning technology, consisting of Fe3Se4 and porous nitrogen-doped carbon nanofibers was designed for the interlayer of LSBs. The porous carbon nanofiber structure facilitates the transport of ions and electrons, while the Fe3Se4 material adsorbs lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) and accelerates its catalytic conversion process. Furthermore, the Fe3Se4 material interacts with soluble LiPSs to generate a new polysulfide intermediate, Li x FeS y complex, which changes the electrochemical reaction pathway and facilitates the three-dimensional deposition of Li2S, enhancing the reversibility of LSBs. The designed LSB demonstrates a high specific capacity of 1529.6 mA h g−1 in the first cycle at 0.2 C. The rate performance is also excellent, maintaining an ultra-high specific capacity of 779.7 mA h g−1 at a high rate of 8 C. This investigation explores the mechanism of the interaction between the interlayer and LiPSs, and provides a new strategy to regulate the reaction kinetics and Li2S deposition in LSBs.
